Award.AwardTitle: URM: Undergraduate Research and Mentoring in Ecological Genomics
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to Kansas State University (KSU) to establish an Undergraduate Research and Mentoring (URM) program. The program will provide up to two-year research experiences in ecological genomics to five cohorts of scholars (six students per cohort) starting in spring 2011 and continuing through winter 2015. Each scholar will be paired with a faculty member linked to the KSU Ecological Genomics Institute, an intercollege research group whose research spans multiple levels in the biological hierarchy. EGI participants seek to understand the genetic mechanisms underlying the short- and long-term organism responses to the natural environment. URM scholars will be integrated into EGI labs where they will develop early in their career (1) an appreciation for integrative scientific approaches to hypothesis based research, (2) critical thinking skills, and (3) a desire to continue their education in graduate level study. By the end of their tenure in the program, scholars will be well positioned for admission into highly competitive graduate programs in ecology and evolution. The KSU-URM program will include three main components: (1) a summer field course, (2) up to two years of independent research, mentored directly by faculty, (3) enhancement activities to foster cohort-building and networking, peer mentoring, communication skills building, ethics training, and career development, and (4) research presentations at professional meetings. Scholars will investigate a diversity of projects built around the expertise of the faculty mentors, including (1) the ecological and evolutionary genomics of adaptation, (2) speciation/hybridization, and evolutionary and comparative genomics, (3) genomics and ecology of species interactions, and (4) population and conservation genomics. Scholars will be selected based on an application packet, academic record, and the desire to create a diverse cohort of URM scholars that span the spectra of gender, racial, disability, and ethnic diversity. Evaluation of program success is planned through monitoring of student accomplishments and outcomes. More information is available at http://ecogen.ksu.edu/, or by contacting Samantha Wisely (wisely@ksu.edu) or Ari Jumpponen (ari@ksu.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our program paired undergraduate students of diverse backgrounds with a diverse selection of faculty mentors in individual and independent research projects. Our bold goal was to train the next generation of competitive workforce and leaders in the expanding and complex field of ecological genomics as well as to provide our students with tools, experience, and expertise to successfully compete for professional career paths. Our program trained 22 undergraduate in 12 faculty mentors' laboratories for a period of one or two years. The students received training in the application of the scientific method, specifically in the general area of ecological genomics. Each participating undergraduate student had a tailored research project united by the umbrella of ecological genomics and the use of cutting edge genetic, genomic, and metagenomic tools. Although six of our students still remain in their undergraduate institution, ten have already entered in graduate training programs or professional schools and are getting further training to become the next generation of professionals either in this complex and demanding field or in the application of tools and approaches with which they became familiar during their training in our program.

 

In the course of the training activities, our undergraduate students were immersed in research in a wide variety of fields in biological sciences. Overall, our student projects covered a broad range either covering fundamental biological questions or addressing more applied management issues. We highlight two examples for each. On the more fundamental biology side, 1) a project including two of our undergraduates identified the potential genes and cell processes that lay foundation to understanding how the transition from unicellular organisms may have proceeded to more complex multicellular organisms leading to the development of multicellularity in eukaryotes; 2) a project including three undergraduate students utilized temperature manipulations in experimental environments and concluded that that insect long-term and short-term acclimation to temperature use different genetic and physiological mechanisms to maintain similar survivorship in a population of organisms. On the more applied side, 1) a project including two of our undergraduates focusing on the dominant tallgrass prairie grass, the big bluestem, concluded that not all seed sources perform equally across a precipitation gradient, but that conservation of grassland systems is best accomplished by understanding which seed sources perform best in any given target restoration area; 2) a project including one of our undergraduates analyzed root associated fungi colonizing ornamental trees in urban greenspaces and concluded that, whilst both native and non-native trees were heavily colonized by the beneficial root symbionts, native and non-native trees hosted distinct communities leading to a recommendation of diverse ornamental tree portfolios to maximize diversity in urban systems.

 

Many of the results that combined the research of our undergraduate students have already been disseminated to target audiences in scientific meetings, in scientific journals, and informally in meetings with local resource managers. Further results from our research program continue to be disseminated to the science community in scientific meetings and to broader audiences in less formal avenues. Overall, our undergraduate program stroke interest in research in a diverse population of undergraduate students and provided them with an exposure to a range of biological research topics and tools. We look forward to seeing our students take advantage of this training in cutting edge analytical tools and establish themselves as the next generation of leaders in biological sciences.
